mL/(h·g) and (b) 30,000 mL/(h·g). [H2]:[CO2] = 4:1. Fig. 2 Synchrotron XRD patterns of the NiO/CeO2 the range of (a) 2θ = 2 − 7° and (b) 2θ = 3.1 − 3.4°, and Ni/CeO2 at the range of (c) 2θ = 2 − 7° and (d) 2θ = 3.7 − 4.0°. Phase compositions: NiO (COD ID: mp-19009), Ni0 (COD ID: 2100643) and CeO2 (COD ID: 1562989). Fig. 3 (a–b) Brightfield TEM images and HAADF STEM-EDX map with Ni (red) and Ce (cyan) shown. (c–d) Ni (111) facet exposed with mask (red) applied for the diffraction contrast image. (e) particle size histogram of Ni (111) reflection. Samples measured: A: Ni/CeO2 (600, air). B: Ni/CeO2 (700, air). C: Ni/CeO2 (600, He). D: Ni/CeO2 (600, NO). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 4 H2-TPR profiles over the NiO/CeO2 (600, NO), NiO/CeO2 (600, He), NiO/CeO2 (600, air) and NiO/CeO2 (700, air), and (b) quantitative analysis of H2 consumption over different Ni species. Fig. 5 (a) Ni K-edge XANES spectra and (b) Fourier-transformed R-space EXAFS spectra of the Ni/CeO2 samples with the k weight. Fig. 6 (a) Quantitative concentration of surface Ni active sites and oxygen vacancies and (b) variation of CO2 conversion at 260 °C (GHSV=271,698 mL/(h·g)) with the total number of catalytically accessible Ni − Ov sites. Fig. 7 In situ DRIFTS spectra of CO2 methanation at 150, 250 and 350 °C over (a) Ni/CeO2 (600, air), (b) Ni/CeO2 (700, air), (c) Ni/CeO2 (600, He) and (d) Ni/CeO2 (600, NO). Fig. 8 Scheme of (a) active interfacial sites and (b) inactive sites on Ni/CeO2 in CO2 methanation. Graphical abstract The structure of a catalyst has a strong impact on its performance. Here we investigate the physicochemical properties of Ni/CeO2 in an attempt to draw structure–activity relationships for CO2 methanation. A combination of characterisation methods (X-ray diffraction (XRD), 4D Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (4D-STEM), CO chemisorption and oxygen storage capacity study etc.) clearly demonstrates the effect of Ni crystallite size, Ni availability (i.e. catalytically accessible Ni) and oxygen vacancies at the Ni-CeO2 interface in Ni/CeO2 during CO2 methanation. Among them, the role of exposed Ni active sites is highlighted, and two possible optimisation schemes i.e. changing the support calcination temperature and the final calcination atmosphere are proposed to obtain a better dispersal of Ni NPs (nanoparticles) on CeO2. Both modification methods do not affect the reaction route, and the activity differences of Ni/CeO2 can be explained by the various hydrogenation rate of formate species, as confirmed by in situ diffuse-reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) measurements. Keywords CO2 methanation Nickel Ceria Structure–activity Metal-support interaction Data availability Processed data from the publication can be accessed via the following link: https://doi.org/10.5522/04/27100954.v1. 1 Introduction The Sabatier reaction, or CO2 methanation represents a facile catalytic reaction to produce synthetic natural gas (CH4) at relatively low temperatures and with high yields [1,2]. Although CO2 methanation is exothermic and can take place spontaneously even at low temperatures (∼30 °C), CO2 conversion and CH4 yield only become significant at temperatures in excess of ∼ 300 °C due to the high kinetic barriers required for CO2 activation [3,4]. A common and often undesired by-product is CO, which may also form at the same time although the extent to which this occurs depends on the catalyst type and composition [5–7]. It is widely acknowledged that in addition to the composition, the structure of the catalyst can affect performance and this conclusion has been gleaned from numerous works performed over the past few decades [8–11]. Typically, the structures of methanation catalysts can be greatly influenced by the supports, the active elements present and the preparation methods. The main catalytic element comprises either base (Ni, Fe, Co etc.) or noble metals (Ru, Rh etc.) [12–16]. Of these, Ni-based catalysts are widely regarded as the most promising for industrial applications due to a combination of their low cost and high performance [11]. Various supports (e.g., Al2O3, SiO2 and CeO2) have also been evaluated, with CeO2 demonstrating consistently to be the best performing not least because of its high oxygen storage capacity and its propensity to stabilise oxygen vacancies [17–24]. Many studies have highlighted the remarkable catalytic performance of Ni/CeO2 in CO2 methanation [25–28]. However, there is an ongoing discussion around whether the activity in CO2 methanation depends on the Ni particle/crystallite size, since it has been proposed that it is a structure-sensitive reaction where not all metal particles have the same activity [29–31]. Hao et al. rationalised that the decrease in the CO2 turnover can be explained by the increase in Ni crystallite size from 8 to 21 nm [32]. A similar observation was made by Lin et al. who prepared a series of Ni/CeO2 with Ni NPs sizes (2 − 8 nm) achieved by depositing pre-synthesized, size-controlled Ni on commercial CeO2 [28]. They observed that the activity followed the following trend; Ni/CeO2 (8 nm) > Ni/CeO2 (4 nm) > Ni/CeO2 (2 nm), emphasizing the structure-sensitivity of CO2 methanation on Ni/CeO2. Meanwhile, Vogt et al. synthesized a range of silica-supported Ni catalysts with Ni sizes varying from 1 to 7 nm, and the impact of Ni size on CO2 methanation was evident [29]. In contrast, Beierlein et al. noted a linear correlation between the conversion and the Ni surface area over Ni-Al2O3, claiming the structure-insensitivity of CO2 methanation [31]. In a recent study by Parastaev et al., it was reported that the structure sensitivity in CO2 hydrogenation can be overcome over Co/CeO2-ZrO2 by adjusting the metal-support interaction (MSI) [30]. In their study, various H2 reduction temperatures (225–500 °C) were employed to alter the metal-support interface, and the partial reduction of cobalt particles at a lower temperature resulted in higher intrinsic activity [30]. For the catalysts utilising reducible supports like CeO2, the MSI can strongly affect the catalyst activity; often this evolves into a strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) where the metal becomes encapsulated by a reduced support layer [33,34]. SMSI can affect the electronic structure of active sites and limit metal migration, leading to an improved catalytic activity and stability [35–37]. For example, a strong charge transfer propensity has been observed over Ru/ZrO2 catalysts exhibiting SMSI and which leads to an improvement in CO2 methanation performance [35]. One possible reason for the enhanced activity could be the presence of more metal-support interfacial sites [38]. The degree of MSI (including but not limited to SMSI) in catalysts can be tuned by exploiting properties such as the metal particle size and support reducibility, which can be achieved by adjusting the temperature of a reductive pretreatment and the calcination temperature/atmosphere [22,30,39,40]. The interaction between metal and support in Co/CeO2-based catalysts was effectively adjusted by varying the particle size/surface area of the support [40]. These variations were obtained through calcination of the support at different temperatures (500–1000 °C). This study demonstrated that the strong MSI achieved on the CeO2-ZrO2 support with a particle size in 20–30 nm range can prevent metal sintering during high-temperature reduction, resulting in a much better catalytic performance in CO2 methanation than others [40]. The negative impact of SMSI on catalytic performance in CO2 methanation has been proposed by Li and co-workers [39]. In their work, the activity and selectivity of Ni/α-TiO2 catalysts were significantly inhibited by an SMSI-induced TiO2 overlayer, leading to CO being generated as the only product. Pre-treatment of the α-TiO2 support through NH3 annealing at 600 °C substantially inhibited the development of a TiO2 overlayer around Ni nanoparticles and exposed more Ni active sites, thereby enhancing CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity [39]. Due to Ni encapsulation via SMSI, the actual number of exposed Ni active sites ends up being much lower than expected, with particularly well-dispersed Ni species blocked by an overlayer of reducible support. Thereby, the term “Ni availability”, defined as the fraction of exposed Ni atoms present on the surface, has been introduced in our work to describe the amount of catalytically available Ni, distinguishing it from the more common concept of Ni dispersion (fraction of Ni atoms present on the surface). Typically, Ni availability in catalysts like Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/SiO2 equates to the Ni dispersion [31,41]. However, in catalysts with reducible supports, such as Ni/CeO2 and Ni/TiO2, Ni availability needs to consider both the Ni dispersion and extent of SMSI [39,42]. Ni availability is really only determinable using “chemical methods” such as TPR/chemisorption in which the reactant molecules can access the catalytically available Ni sites [39], whereas Ni dispersion is ideally determined in parallel with physicochemical characterisation methods such as XRD and TEM [31,32]. Therefore, it can be said that the presence of the Ni–CeO2 interface in Ni/CeO2, greatly influenced by factors such as Ni particle size, Ni availability, oxygen vacancies, and metal-support interaction, is widely acknowledged as the primary reason for its superior activity compared to other Ni catalysts on non-reducible supports [20,21,43]. For Ni/CeO2 prepared via a ‘plasma method’, the enriched Ni-CeO2 interfacial sites were considered as the main reason for its enhanced activity (e.g. 50 % higher at 275 °C) than Ni/CeO2 prepared by conventional thermal treatment, resulting in the decrease in Ni crystallite size (from 15.5 to 9.8 nm) and increase in oxygen vacancy concentration (from around 28 to 31 %) [20]. In work by Ye et al. using a sol–gel method to prepare a Ni/CeO2 catalyst and who compared its performance with a catalyst prepared by a conventional impregnation method, the best performing catalysts were rationalised in terms of the better-dispersed Ni metal (from 1.1 to 6.4 %), a smaller Ni particle size (from 8.3 to 6.4 nm) and the presence of more oxygen vacancies (from 49.2 to 73.3 %) [21]. The main problem when changing the preparation method to effect differences in catalytic performance is that it tends to result in the simultaneous changing of multiple properties of the catalyst (i.e., Ni crystallite/particle size, oxygen vacancy concentration etc.), obfuscating an understanding of the role of a specific property. Some work has attempted to bring clarity to the question of salient catalyst characteristics for example, Ni crystallite size [28,32]. In that regard, the most straightforward method to control the size is by simply tuning the Ni loading, though, in addition to crystallite size, this also affects the Ni dispersion [32,44]. Moreover, metal-support interactions which can be tuned by particle size and support reducibility, also affects the metal availability during the reaction, leading to uncertainties in the distinct contributions of each property [39,45,46]. The effect of thermal treatment in different atmospheres (H2, N2 and air) on Ni/CeO2 were compared by Lin et al. [22]. They proposed that the direct activation of Ni on CeO2 by H2 without thermal treatment in inert (N2) or oxidative (air) gas can lead to a crucial metal-support interaction, essential for the formation of highly dispersed Ni NPs and an increased concentration of surface oxygen vacancies [22]. An alternative reducing gas, 0.1 or 1 % nitric oxide (NO) in He, was also utilized for nitrate decomposition and demonstrated to notably improve the dispersion of Ni on SiO2 [41]. However, it remains uncertain whether a comparable effect can be observed after the calcination of Ni nitrate/CeO2 under NO atmosphere. In this study, we prepared a series of 10 wt. % Ni on CeO2 catalysts using the same synthesis method (incipient wetness impregnation). The structure of the catalysts were adjusted by modulating the MSI through changes in the calcination temperature of CeO2 as well as the treatment of the final supported Ni/CeO2. An in-depth characterisation and performance study of these Ni/CeO2 catalysts was subsequently conducted to evaluate the role of (i) the Ni crystallite/particle size and speciation, (ii) Ni availability (i.e. catalytically accessible Ni), (iii) oxygen vacancy concentration and (iv) the metal-support interaction on the formation of the Ni-CeO2 interface. A quantitative analysis was applied to clarify the composition of Ni-(O)-Ce interfacial sites. For instance, does a higher concentration of available Ni sites or surface oxygen vacancies invariably lead to increased activity, and is there any correlation between any two of these factors in the formation of the interface? These results will allow for determining how these parameters influence the catalytic performance and to see which of these parameters appears most significant as far as the catalyst’s light-off temperature is concerned. 2 Experimental The methods used in this paper can be divided into three parts, comprising the preparation of the catalysts, activity evaluation and characterisation of samples. 2.1 Preparation The preparation of the catalysts can be divided into three parts in chronological order: (1) calcination of the CeO2 at different temperatures (600 and 700 °C); (2) preparation of NiO/CeO2 in different atmospheres (1 % NO/He, He and static air); and finally (3) reduction to Ni/CeO2 at 500 °C. Firstly, a series of supports (CeO2) were prepared by calcining Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (Sigma Aldrich, 99 %) at 600 and 700 °C, respectively for 3 h in static air. The obtained Ce supports were labelled as CeO2 (600) and CeO2 (700), respectively. Then, to achieve a 10 wt% Ni loading, 1.98 g Ni(NO3)2·9H2O (Sigma Aldrich, 99 %) was dissolved into water, and the incipient wetness method was used for adding the Ni to 4 g CeO2. The NiO/CeO2 catalysts were obtained after calcining dried Ni(NO3)2/CeO2 at 500 °C for 3 h under static air.. The NiO/CeO2 were differentiated based on the calcination temperature of the initial CeO2 precursor, therefore NiO/CeO2 (600) and NiO/CeO2 (700), respectively. All NiO/CeO2 samples were then reduced in a H2/He gas mixture for 1 h to give Ni/CeO2 (600) and Ni/CeO2 (700). It should be noted that the final calcination temperature of all samples was the same (500 °C). For the catalysts prepared under different atmospheres, the Ni(NO3)2/CeO2 (600) precursors were calcined under static air, He flowing and 1 % NO/He flowing in the tube furnace, respectively. The calcined and final reduced samples are labelled as NiO/CeO2 (600, air), NiO/CeO2 (600, He), NiO/CeO2 (600, NO), Ni/CeO2 (600, air), Ni/CeO2 (600, He) and Ni/CeO2 (600, NO), respectively. 2.2 Characterisation The specific surface area, pore volume and pore size of the different samples were measured by using a Quardrasorb SI model SI-20 Quantachrome instrument. All the samples were firstly degassed at 110 °C overnight using a Flovac Degasser FVD-3 Quantachrome instrument and then measured using N2 adsorption and desorption at − 196 °C. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were recorded on a Rigaku Miniflex X-ray diffractometer using a 600 W X-ray tube source and CuKα radiation (λ = 0.155418 nm). Data were acquired over a 2θ range of 20 − 80° with the scan rate of 1°/min and a step size of 0.02°. Synchrotron XRD analysis of the NiO/CeO2 and Ni/CeO2 samples were conducted on the ID31 beamline at the European Synchrotron Radiation Facility (ESRF) using a Pilatus3 X CdTe 2 M detector. X-ray energy was 91 keV with the wavelength of around 0.13624 Å and the beam size was 400 × 500 μm2. The powder samples were well sieved and placed into a quartz capillary with the diameter and wall thickness of 0.5 and 0.01 mm. PyFAI was used for the calibration and integration of the data analysis [47]. The Scherrer equation was used for the calculation of mean CeO2, NiO and Ni0 crystallite sizes. The assumption was made that the crystallites adopt the shape of a sphere, which was also applied when using the Scherrer equation [48]. The Rietveld refinement of synchrotron XRD profiles was conducted using HighScore Plus software to determine the relative proportions of crystalline phases of Ni(O) and CeO2. Reference CIF files corresponding to NiO (COD ID: mp-19009), Ni (COD ID: 2100643), and CeO2 (COD ID: 1562989) were utilized in the analysis. Key refinement parameters included (i) background fitting (polynomial), (ii) scale factor, (iii) unit cell and (iv) profile variables (U/V/W left) etc. The refinement process ensured that the weighted profile R-factor (Rwp) and the goodness of fit were typically < 10 and 2 respectively, indicating a high-quality fit [49]. The Ni loading of the catalysts was determined by the Epsilon3-XL X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (XRF). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was carried out using a Thermo Fisher Scientific NEXSA spectrometer with monochromatic Al Kα (1486.6 eV) radiation using the HarwellXPS facility. The charging effects of samples were compensated by calibrating all binding energy (BE) values against the C 1 s peak of adventitious carbon at 284.6 eV. The obtained data were analysed using the CasaXPS 2.3.24 software. Samples for 4D Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (4D-STEM) were prepared by dispersing samples in methanol by sonication (30 mins), before drop-casting onto 300 mesh holey carbon films on copper grids (Agar, UK). High-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy mapping was performed at the University of Leeds Electron Microscopy and Spectroscopy Centre using an TESCAN TENSOR. The software Nano Measurer 1.2 was used to calculate particle sizes. Hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) over various samples were conducted on a ChemBET 3000 flow analyser. Around 100 mg of sample was placed into a U-type quartz reactor cell for each measurement. The thermal conductivity detector (TCD) signals were recorded in 5 % H2/Ar gas flow from room temperature to 900 °C with a ramp of 10 °C /min. CO chemisorption experiments were also carried out by using ChemBET. 50 mg NiO/CeO2 was loaded and reduced in 20 % H2/Ar at 500 °C for 1 h. After He purge at 500 °C for 1 h, 10 % CO/He pulse was periodically injected into the reduced sample at 30 °C until saturation. The blank test on the CeO2 support were also measured. Ni availability of Ni/CeO2 was estimated by deducting the amount of CO chemisorbed on CeO2. H2-TPD measurements were also applied in ChemBET for Ni availability estimation. 200 mg NiO/CeO2 was reduced in 20 % H2/Ar at 500 °C for 1 h, followed by He flowing at 500 °C for another 1 h. After cooling and stabilisation at 30 °C, 20 % H2/He gas flow was introduced into system for H2 adsorption. After 2 h, the samples were purged by He again for 30 min. Then, the TCD signals were recorded in pure He gas flow from 30 to 500 °C with a ramp of 10 °C /min. Ni dispersion was estimated by the mean size of Ni particles (dNi, nm) measured in STEM (Eq. (1)) [28]. The number of expected surface Ni active sites (NNi-sites, expected) can be estimated by Eq. (2) whereas Ni availability estimated through CO chemisorption and H2-TPD can be calculated with the following equations (Eqs. (3)–(4)). The corresponding number of exposed Ni active siharacterisation was performed to evaluate the importance of properties such as Ni crystallite size, availability and oxygen vacanciestes (NNi-sites, H2/CO mmol/g) were determined using Eqs. (5)–(6). (1) D Ni = 1.18 d Ni × 100% (2) N Ni-sites, expected = ω × D Ni M Ni × 10 3 (3) A Ni, CO = V CO × M Ni W cat × ω × V m × 100% (4) A Ni, H2 = 2V H × M Ni W cat × ω × V m × 100% (5) N Ni-sites, CO = V CO W cat × V m × 10 3 (6) N Ni-sites, H2 = 2V H W cat × V m × 10 3 Where, VCO and VH is the volume (L) of chemisorbed CO in chemisorption and desorbed H2 in H2-TPD, respectively. The W cat and ω are the mass of catalyst (g) and the Ni mass fraction, respectively. The corresponding values of the gas molar volume (Vm) and Ni molecular weight (MNi) are 22.4 L/mol and 58.69 g/mol. Ni coverage caused by SMSI can be estimated from the following equation (Eq. (7)). (7) Ni coverage % = N Ni-sites, expected - N Ni-sites, H2/CO N Ni-sites, expected × 100% Oxygen storage capacity complete (OSCC) measurements were also performed on the ChemBET 3000 flow analyser by injecting an O2 pulse periodically into the reduced Ni/CeO2 samples. 50 mg NiO/CeO2 was loaded and reduced in 20 % H2/Ar at 500 °C for 1 h. At this temperature (500 °C), an O2 pulse was periodically injected into the sample until saturation. The consumption of oxygen was calculated and defined as the OSCtotal. The consumption of oxygen by Ni is defined as OSCNi which is calculated on the assumption that all Ni metal can be oxidised to NiO at 500 °C, and a H2-TPR experiment of the Ni/CeO2 (600, air) sample which was oxidised during OSC measurement was carried out to confirm this assumption. Then the OSCC can be quantificationally determined by the following equation: (8) OSCC = OSC total - OSC Ni Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (DRIFTS) studies over various catalysts were performed on an Agilent Vertex 70 FTIR spectrometer (FTS 3000 MX) quipped with ZnSe windows. For transient reactions, all the catalysts were first reduced at 500 °C under 50 % H2/He, followed by cooling to reaction temperature. The background was collected at this temperature after a He purge for 20 min. CO2 adsorption was then conducted in a 20 % CO2/He gas flow for 30 min. The first spectrum was collected after He purging for 20 min. After that, 80 % H2/He was introduced for reaction. A series of spectra were collected after 1, 2, 3, 5, 10 and 20 min. For each spectrum, 64 scans were collected over the mid − IR (400 − 4000 cm−1) range. All the catalysts were studied using the above method at the reaction temperature of 250 and 350 °C, respectively. Ni K-edge (8333 eV) X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy (XAS) was performed at beamline B18 of Diamond Light Source. Measurements were collected using a double crystal Si (111) monochromator. Rejection of higher order harmonics was done using a harmonic rejection mirror. Powder samples (12 mg) were pressed into pellets (diameter = 13 mm) after mixing with cellulose (50 mg), and all XAFS results were collected in transmission mode and obtained simultaneously with the Ni foil placed between It and Iref. The scanning time for each spectrum was around 3 min with a kmax up to 14, and 3 scans were averaged to improve the signal to noise level in the data. For Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (EXAFS) analysis, IFEFFIT (Athena and Artemis) was used [50]. Only the first shell was fitted for all samples over a radial distance of 1–3 Å. 2.3 Activity evaluation During the test, two setups were used operating at different Gas Hourly Space Velocities (GHSV), namely a fixed-bed tubular quartz reactor with 1 cm of diameter operating at 271,698 mL/(h·g) and a CATLAB microreactor (Hiden Analytical, UK) operating at 30,000 mL/(h·g). CO2 conversion (XCO2) and CH4 selectivity (SCH4) of all tests for each set temperature was estimated using Eqs. ((9)–(10)). (9) X CO 2 % = [ CO 2 ] in - [ CO 2 ] out [ CO 2 ] in × 100 % (10) S C H 4 % = [ CH 4 ] out [CO] out + [ CH 4 ] out × 100 % In the tubular quartz reactor, 53 mg of sample with a particle size 0.425–0.595 mm was diluted with 470 mg quartz for each test. Before the reaction, the sample was firstly reduced in 50 % H2/N2 with the total flow rate of 200 mL/min at 500 °C for 1 h. After cooling down and stabilisation, the reaction was carried out with the following gas composition ([H2]:[CO2]:[N2] = 4:1:1) in the oven temperature range of 200–350 °C (temperature interval 20 to 300 °C) at 1 bar with a total flow rate of 240 mL/min. The GHSV was 271,698 mL/(h·g). A K-type thermowell was placed inside the reactor to measure temperature profiles in the catalytic bed. The exit gases were quantified through a micro-GC Agilent technologies 990 to evaluate CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity (Eqs. (9)–10)). For the measurements performed in the microreactor, 50 mg of sample was placed in the fixed bed reactor tube of the Hiden CATLAB which is connected to the Quadrupole mass spectrometer. Before the activity test, the samples were initially reduced in 50 % H2/He at 500 °C for 1 h under 1 bar gas with the total flow rate of 100 mL/min. After cooling down to 150 °C and stabilising for 1 h, the feed gas ([H2]:[CO2]:[N2] = 4:1:1) was introduced for the activity evaluation with a GHSV=30,000 mL/(h·g). For the activity test under steady-state conditions, the samples were tested in the temperature range of 250 − 450 °C and the testing time at each temperature was 30 min. The turnover frequencies (TOF) of CO2 at 260 °C over these samples are also estimated by Eq. (11) [51]. (11) TOF s - 1 = X C O 2 × F CO2 × M Ni × 10 - 3 60 × V m × W cat × ω × A Ni Where, XCO2 is the CO2 conversion (%), FCO2 is the flow rate of CO2 in the reaction (mL/min), Vm is gas molar volume (22.4 L/mol), Wcat is the weight of catalyst used (g), ω is the mass fraction of Ni in Ni/CeO2 (%), MNi is molar mass of Ni (58.69 g/mol) and ANi is Ni availability (%). CO hydrogenation activity tests were also performed over different catalysts in the microreactor. 50 mg of oxide sample was loaded into the reactor tube. Samples were initially reduced before reaction in 50 % H2/He at 500 °C, followed by the MS signal stabilization at 150 °C. Dynamic temperature-programmed reaction was performed in the mixture of CO, H2 and balanced gas He with the reaction temperature increasing from 150 to 400 °C at the heating rate of 10 °C /min. For the NiO/CeO2 (600, air) and NiO/CeO2 (700, air), the activities were evaluated with the GHSV=15,000 mL/(h·g) ([H2]:[CO2]:[N2] = 4:1:15). Total flow rate was 50 ml/min. The activity comparison of the samples calcined under different atmospheres was conducted at a higher GHSV of 30, 000 mL/(h·g) with the flow rate ratio of H2: CO: He = 4:1:9. The total flow rate was 70 ml/min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Assessment of catalytic performance For methanation, CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity are the two important parameters for performance evaluation [11,52,53], which can be seen in Fig. 1 . The catalytic performance of methanation was evaluated at around 270,000 mL/(h·g) and 30,000 mL/(h·g). As illustrated in Fig. 1(a), it can be seen that all catalysts are active at around 260 °C at the higher GHSV and that the Ni/CeO2 (600) sample exhibits the greatest CO2 conversion over the temperature range of 260–350 °C. The CO2 methanation ability of Ni/CeO2 can be affected by both the support calcination temperature and calcination atmosphere, with the CO2 conversion at low temperatures (below 300 °C) following the trend Ni/CeO2 (600, NO) > Ni/CeO2 (600, air) > Ni/CeO2 (600, He) > Ni/CeO2 (700, air). The overall CO2 conversion differences among the Ni/CeO2 is confirmed at the lower GHSV=30,000 mL/(h·g), as shown in Fig. 1(b). The CO2 conversion values of these Ni/CeO2 catalysts measured under this condition are significantly higher than those obtained at the higher GHSV=271,698 mL/(h·g), although the trend of catalyst activity measured under both conditions is similar. For the optimal Ni/CeO2 (600, NO) catalyst at the GHSV=30,000 mL/(h·g), its T50 (temperature when CO2 conversion = 50 %) is lower by 25 °C compared to the Ni/CeO2 (600, air), with the T50 value being ∼ 240 °C. The CH4 selectivity at 220–350 °C for the different samples is also given at the top of Fig. 1(a). Similar CH4 selectivity can be seen for all samples, maintaining at 85–95 % across the temperature range profiled. The CH4 selectivity witnesses a slight increase as the temperature increases from 220 to 260 °C, and the difference among all samples gradually disappears. With the temperature climbing to 350 °C, there is a slight drop-off in CH4 selectivity over all catalysts. It should be noted however, that the CH4 selectivity is similar and always above 85 % in the temperature range of 220–350 °C for all samples. Separate CO hydrogenation activity tests for the Ni/CeO2 indicate that CO is only partially converted to CH4 (Fig. S1). This observation helps us rationalise the types of intermediates and reaction pathways apparent in Ni/CeO2 (vide infra). 3.2 Phase composition, structure and textural properties The crystalline phase composition of the different NiO/CeO2 and Ni/CeO2 were firstly determined by synchrotron XRD analysis, as displayed in Fig. 2 . In the lab-based XRD characterisation with Cu Kα radiation, compared to CeO2, the intensities of Ni reflections are much weaker and suffer from poor signal-to-noise rendering accurate full width at half maximum (FWHM) values of Ni(O) species difficult to determine (Fig. S3). In order to obtain more reliable FWHM data, high energy synchrotron XRD measurements were performed to obtain the high-resolution XRD profiles shown in Fig. 2. For the calcined NiO/CeO2 catalysts, the NiO phase can be seen in Fig. 2(a) with two obvious reflections located at 2θ range of 3–4° (COD ID: mp-19009), corresponding to NiO (111) and NiO (200). After reduction in H2 atmosphere and passivation in low concentration of O2, two new reflections (2θ = 3.8 and 4.3°) assigned to be the Ni0 species (COD ID: 2100643) can be seen to arise due to NiO reduction in Fig. 2(d). The NiO, Ni and CeO2 crystallite sizes over different samples were calculated and compared in Table 1 . For pure CeO2 prepared at 600 and 700 °C, the crystallite size is affected by the calcination temperature, although these values (11–13 nm) could be considered to be very similar. Ni addition and calcination further increase the CeO2 crystallite size of all samples by 2–4 nm. Similarly, the enlargement of CeO2 crystallites also takes place after reduction. The increase in CeO2 crystallite sizes can be ascribed to the effects of thermal treatment [54]. The mean crystallite sizes of NiO are determined to be 14, 17, 15 and 14 nm over the Ni/CeO2 (600, air), Ni/CeO2 (700, air) Ni/CeO2 (600, He) and Ni/CeO2 (600, NO), respectively. After reduction, the crystallite size of Ni in all the reduced samples span the narrow range of 13–15 nm, with the value in Ni/CeO2 (600, air), Ni/CeO2 (700, air), Ni/CeO2 (600, He) and Ni/CeO2 (600, NO) being 13, 15, 13 and 13 nm, respectively. It is observed that bigger Ni NPs form on CeO2 (700), while they are very similar on other catalysts. In order to have a better understanding of the Ni particle size over different catalysts, the 4D-STEM data were collected using STEM-EDX, selected area electron diffraction (SAED) and diffraction contrast imaging (Fig. 3 ). The brightfield TEM images and EDX maps are given in Fig. 3(a) and (b). It can be seen that the Ni particles are hard to observe since the support element Ce, which has the greater atomic mass, is too heavy to form an amplitude contrast with Ni. After the collection of the pixelated diffraction dataset, the red mask was applied by exposing the specific Ni(111) facet (Fig. 3(c)). The diffraction contrast images with the Ni(111) species highlighted as the bright spots were then achieved after inverse Fourier transformation, as shown in Fig. 3(d). The particle counts of Ni/CeO2 (600, air), Ni/CeO2 (700, air), Ni/CeO2 (600, He) and Ni/CeO2 (600, NO) collected using diffraction contrast (Fig. 3(d)) confirm the wide distribution of Ni particles with a mean diameter of approximately 7.0, 8.8, 6.6 and 5.1 nm, respectively. This conclusion was made based on the assumption that the metallic Ni with the face-centred cubic (FCC) structure is approximately spherical. A likely explanation for the size discrepancy between XRD and STEM results is that the sample possesses a polydisperse Ni crystallite distribution and the XRD data shows a bias towards the larger crystallites [55]. One might expect a clear trend between mean Ni NP size i.e. Ni/CeO2 (600, NO) and the CO2 methanation performance observed (Fig. 1). However, Ni/CeO2 (600, He) exhibits a smaller mean Ni NP size than Ni/CeO2 (600, air) although it does not show a better activity. This observation indicates a role of other parameters on catalyst performance (vide infra). The presence of the SMSI phenomenon in different Ni/CeO2 samples can be observed by the decrease in the surface Ni/Ce atomic ratios after H2 reduction (Table S2). The accessible Ni sites were then determined respectively by CO chemisorption and H2-TPD to identify the amount of accessible Ni metal which are not affected by possible SMSI effects [39,46], and are given in Table 1. Since the sample was first reduced at 500 °C, the subsequent He purging at the same temperature (500 °C) may not completely remove the H atoms on the Ni metal, which can be evidenced by formate species forming during simple CO2 adsorption (Fig. S10). This means that some Ni sites were probably occupied by H atoms, resulting in a lower extent of CO chemisorption than the actual available Ni. In addition, the formation of Ni carbonyl species might occur rendering the precise CO/Ni stoichiometry uncertain and complicating the measurement of accessible Ni sites [56]. However, it has been suggested that Ni carbonyl formation primarily occurs on well-dispersed Ni catalysts with crystallite sizes (<4 nm) [56,57]. However, in this study, the crystallite size of all samples, as determined by the Scherrer equation, are larger than 10 nm, and CO chemisorption was conducted at a relative low temperature (approximately room temperature), which potentially minimises this effect. In the H2-TPD process, H2 uptake typically involves irreversible and reversible adsorption, and tends to result in a much higher value than the actual accessible Ni surface [58]. In addition, H2 spillover might take place during H2 chemisorption, resulting in a higher Ni availability than the expected value [59]. Therefore, the data reported here based on the two measurement methods can only give a general trend for the different samples, and the actual concentration of accessible Ni sites on Ni/CeO2 might be somewhere between the values obtained from CO chemisorption and H2-TPD. By combining these two methods however, a more reliable trend of Ni availability over different catalysts can be established. While absolute values for Ni availability may not be fully accurate, this approach allows for a clearer understanding of how Ni availability varies between catalysts. The Ni availability, as determined by subtracting the amount of CO chemisorbed on pure CeO2, exhibits the following trend: Ni/CeO2 (600, NO) (2.8 %) > Ni/CeO2 (600, air) (2.3 %) > Ni/CeO2 (600, He) (1.8 %) > Ni/CeO2 (700, air) (1.2 %). The Ni availability estimated through H2-TPD in contrast are 5.9, 4.9, 4.1 and 2.9 % in Ni/CeO2 (600, NO), Ni/CeO2 (600, air), Ni/CeO2 (600, He) and Ni/CeO2 (700, air), respectively. The same trend observed in both sets of data is consistent with the work by Siestma et al. where it was shown that NO calcination enhances the Ni dispersion/availability of the supported catalyst [41]. The same ranking in Ni availability and methanation performance (Table 1 & Fig. 1) suggests a positive role of Ni availability in CO2 methanation. It should be noted in this study that Ni availability generally is inversely correlated with Ni crystallite size, apart from the Ni/CeO2 (600, He) sample. For the anomalous Ni/CeO2 (600, He) sample which exhibits small Ni NPs but a low Ni availability, the Ni coverage by CeO2 via SMSI is expected to be very significant. The extent of Ni coverage caused by a SMSI over different Ni/CeO2 catalysts can be compared by the quantitative estimation of actual exposed Ni sites from Ni availability and the expected Ni sites from Ni dispersion (Eq. (7), Table S3). The higher Ni coverage is likely suggesting a greater extent of SMSI. From the results using H2-TPD to measure the number of exposed Ni sites, the extent of SMSI in different Ni/CeO2 can be ranked as follows: Ni/CeO2 (700, air) (ca. 71 %) > Ni/CeO2 (600, He) (ca. 70 %) > Ni/CeO2 (600, NO) (ca. 65 %) > Ni/CeO2 (600, air) (ca. 62 %). No direct correlation between Ni crystallite size and SMSI extent was observed. However, it can be suggested that the calcination temperature of support and calcination atmosphere for Ni decomposition can significantly influence the strength of the potential SMSI. The turnover frequencies (TOF) of CO2 at 260 °C over these samples are also displayed in Table 2 . Considering the different Ni availability calculated from CO chemisorption and H2-TPD analysis, two sets of TOFCO2 values are given. The TOFCO2 at 260 °C estimated through CO chemisorption are respectively 0.76, 0.71, 0.78 and 0.73 s−1 over the Ni/CeO2 (600, air), Ni/CeO2 (700, air), Ni/CeO2 (600, He) and Ni/CeO2 (600, NO), while all these values decrease to around 0.35 s−1 if the Ni availability estimated through H2-TPD is used. In CO2 hydrogenation reactions, it is proposed that the effect of structure-sensitivity is greater on the TOF for metal NPs with diameters from 2 to 4 nm, with the higher TOF achieved on bigger particle. However, when the NPs are much larger, the effect of the SMSI on the TOF is more obvious, resulting in a similar or even smaller TOF for bigger NPs [29,60,61]. The similarity of CO2 turnover frequency (TOFCO2, s−1) over different samples further indicates the CO2 methanation of Ni/CeO2 is ‘size-independent’ when Ni particle sizes vary over 5 − 9 nm and the catalytic performance of different samples in this study could be determined by the total number of exposed Ni atoms. Given the similar Ni loadings (10 wt%) in all Ni/CeO2 catalysts, Ni availability, positively correlated with the total number of Ni atoms exposed to the reactant and therefore can be considered the determining factor for catalytic performance. The actual Ni loadings in different NiO/CeO2 were also measured using XRF, and which were all determined to be close to the initial target value (10 wt%) used in the preparation (data also reported in Table 1). However, the relative concentration of the crystalline (NiO, Ni and CeO2) species determined from analysis of the XRD data on the different samples varies according to Rietveld refinement (Table S4). The Ni loadings calculated based on the NiO crystalline content in NiO/CeO2 (600, air), NiO/CeO2 (700, air) NiO/CeO2 (600, He) and NiO/CeO2 (600, NO) were found to be 9.6, 10.0, 9.5 and 9.4 wt%, respectively. The reduced NiO crystalline content could be due to the presence of ultrasmall NiO undetectable by XRD which was confirmed by TEM [21]. The relative Ni loadings determined from the reduced Ni/CeO2 (600, air), Ni/CeO2 (700, air) Ni/CeO2 (600, He) and Ni/CeO2 (600, NO) samples are approximately 9.1, 9.6, 7.2 and 6.7 wt%, respectively. The decreased Ni0 crystalline concentration could be explained by the formation of Ni2+ species lacking long range order subsequently identified by XANES (vide infra). 3.3 Reducibility The H2-TPR analysis of different samples were then performed to determine the reducibility and the extent of the metal-support interaction (MSI), with the reduction performance displayed in Fig. 4 . A similar reduction behaviour (reduction temperature and types) of NiO seen for all the Ni/CeO2 samples indicates the presence of similar NiO species irrespective of the treatment temperature and gas atmosphere [38]. In order to differentiate between the reduction features over different NiO/CeO2 samples, the overlapping H2 consumption peaks were fitted using a Gaussian function. This allows for the division of the TPR data into three main responses comprising the reduction of; physically adsorbed oxygen species (α), NiO species on CeO2 (β) and CeO2 (γ) [21,31,62]. Reduction of the CeO2 usually takes place at 300–600 °C (reduction of surface lattice oxygen species) and particularly above 750 °C as bulk CeO2 reduces [63–68] (Fig. S7). The NiO species on CeO2 are divided into three types according to their different reduction temperatures. All samples exhibit an intense H2 consumption peak β1, centred between 300 and 330 °C, corresponding to the reduction of bulky NiO particles weakly supported on CeO2 [21,22,69]. Compared to NiO/CeO2 (700, air), the reduction process of NiO/CeO2 (600, air), NiO/CeO2 (600, He) and NiO/CeO2 (600, NO) are more complicated, especially NiO/CeO2 (600, NO). The peaks β2 and β3 are widely ascribed to the reduction process of well-dispersed NiO species which are smaller and closely connected with the CeO2 [19,38]. This is consistent with the STEM results that Ni/CeO2 (600, NO) possesses the smallest mean size of Ni NPs. The presence of peak β4, only observed in NiO/CeO2 (700 °C, air), is likely associated with the reduction of Ni species that form a solid-solution with the CeO2 structure [31]. It's worth noting that the NiO species embedded in the CeO2 structure (peak β4) is hard to reduce into metallic Ni during the initial reduction treatment (500 °C). The overall metal-support interaction (MSI), affecting charge transfer, the interfacial perimeter, nanoparticle morphology, chemical composition and strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) [70], in NiO/CeO2 prepared under different atmospheres can be evaluated by the relative concentration of closely interacted NiO species on the support (β2 and β3), with the extent of metal-support interaction ranking in the order of NiO/CeO2 (600, NO) > NiO/CeO2 (600, He) ∼ NiO/CeO2 (600, air) (Fig. 4(a)). These β2 and β3 species representing Ni NPs in close contact with CeO2 support and with an extensive Ni–CeO2 interface on Ni/CeO2 (600, NO) are thought to be particularly beneficial for the activity at lower temperatures (Fig. 1) due to the charge transfer and/or H2 spillover during the reaction [70]. Quantitative analysis of H2 consumption over different NiO species were also conducted, as exhibited in Fig. 4(b). For the optimal Ni/CeO2 (600, NO) catalyst, the largest amount of H2 consumption due to the peaks β2 and β3 (at ca. 357 and ca. 438 °C) is achieved (ca. 0.17 mmol/g) during the H2 reduction. 3.4 X-ray Absorption spectroscopy (XAS) studies The Ni K-edge XAS measurements over the reduced & passivated catalysts were then performed for a better understanding of the chemical state and local structure information around the Ni. The XANES spectra of the samples were firstly compared with NiO and Ni foil for information on the overall Ni oxidation state. The edge position determined to be typically 50 % of the rising absorption edge intensity is one of the course indicators for Ni oxidation state [71,72]. Here, all the Ni/CeO2 samples can be seen to possess a similar edge energy at around 8333 eV, which coincides with the position of the Ni foil, indicating the existence of metallic Ni. It can also be clearly seen in Fig. 5 (a) that the reference samples NiO and Ni foil possess different white-line intensities. For the catalytic samples, the intensities of the signals located at the white-line position are between the intensities of the two reference samples, demonstrating the presence of some NiO in all Ni/CeO2 samples. Subsequently, linear combination fitting (LCF) was used to estimate their NiO and Ni0 proportion, with the fitting results displayed in Table S5. The large χ2 values obtained from the fitting results shown in Table S5 suggest an imperfect fit to the data possibly due to the presence of non-bulk Ni/NiO species. However, the percentage of NiO over the range 8313 to 8363 eV are respectively 20.5, 30.0, 32.4 and 39.3 % for Ni/CeO2 (600, air), Ni/CeO2 (600, He), Ni/CeO2 (600, NO) and Ni/CeO2 (700, air). The content of NiO species in LCF should ideally be closely correlated with Ni availability, assuming there is no impact of SMSI on the Ni oxidation and all NiO species can be reduced into metallic Ni after reduction, with NiO formation being more significant in the sample possessing higher Ni availability. However, the highest concentration of NiO species is observed on Ni/CeO2 (700, air), which possesses the largest mean Ni crystallite size and the lowest Ni availability. This difference may be attributed to the presence of some Ni2+ species embedded in the CeO2 structure remaining after H2 reduction at 500 °C (Fig. 4) in Ni/CeO2 (700, air). In addition, a different trend between Ni availability and NiO content in LCF is also seen in other Ni/CeO2 catalysts that can be fully reduced in H2 at 500 °C (Fig. 4), indicating different levels of SMSI across these catalysts. Compared to Ni/CeO2 (600, air), the Ni/CeO2 (600, He) which shows a lower Ni availability and possesses more NiO content according to LCF, demonstrating a stronger SMSI. This is in agreement with the apparent contradiction between crystallite size and Ni availability, as discussed above. Therefore, apart from the Ni crystallite size, the SMSI is also a significant contributor affecting the concentration of exposed Ni sites in Ni/CeO2. EXAFS analysis was also carried out with the uncorrected Fourier transformed (FT) EXAFS spectra exhibited in Fig. 5(b). All samples are dominated by a strong peak in the FT at 2 Å followed by 3 weaker peaks between 3 − 5 Å and which is typical of face-centred cubic (fcc) metallic Ni. No evidence can be seen in the fitting results in Fig. S8(a) of the first shell for the presence of Ni − O despite the clear presence of NiO in the XANES, indicating the possible existence of a thin, diffraction silent NiO layer covering the Ni NPs. The following trend in FT intensities was observed in Fig. 5(b) Ni foil > Ni/CeO2 (600, air) > Ni/CeO2 (600, He) > Ni/CeO2 (600, NO) > Ni/CeO2 (700, air) and is negatively correlated with the concentration of NiO seen in XANES. These trends are also borne out in the EXAFS fitting where based on only Ni − Ni (metallic Ni) being present the C.N. of Ni − Ni bonds from metallic Ni for Ni/CeO2 (600, air), Ni/CeO2 (600, He), Ni/CeO2 (600, NO) and Ni/CeO2 (700, air) are around 8.7 ± 0.9, 8.1 ± 1.1, 7.7 ± 1.3 and 7.7 ± 1.7, respectively. The reduction of C.N. of Ni − Ni bonds from metallic Ni in Ni/CeO2 can be explained by the higher concentration of Ni2+ species from the unreduced NiO and different Ni exposure degree. 3.5 Oxygen storage capacity (OSC) studies The oxygen storage capacity measurements of different samples were employed to estimate the concentration of oxygen defects, as displayed in Table 3 . The NiO/CeO2 were reduced in a H2 flow at 500 °C for the reduction of NiO and surface Ce species. At this temperature, almost all NiO species can be reduced into metallic Ni, excluding part of NiO/CeO2 (700), and no reduction of bulk CeO2 can be observed (Fig. 4). O2 injection was also conducted on the reduced Ni/CeO2 at 500 °C, as the Ni0 species are expected to readily oxidise to NiO at this temperature (Fig. S9) [73]. Taking into account the potential oxygen migration from the surface to lattice of CeOx, the oxygen storage capacity obtained from all O2 pulses, termed oxygen storage capacity complete (OSCC), reflects the bulk oxygen defects in all catalysts. Except for the Ni/CeO2 (700, air), all other catalysts were prepared using the same CeO2 support. Hence, the comparison of the surface oxygen vacancies in these catalysts should be reflected to some extent by the trend in OSCC. Compared to the Ni/CeO2 (600, air) (320 μmol O g−1), the OSCC value of Ni/CeO2 (700, air) (172 μmol O g−1) at 500 °C shows a marked decrease indicating the negative effect of a higher calcination temperature of CeO2 on the oxygen vacancy concentration. Both Ni/CeO2 (600, He) and Ni/CeO2 (600, NO) give a higher OSCC value of around 372 and 398 μmol O g−1, respectively, much larger than the Ni/CeO2 (600, air) (320 μmol O g−1), which demonstrates the enhanced concentration of oxygen vacancies on the NO and He calcined samples. The activity shown in Fig. 1 shows that the Ni/CeO2 (600, He) sample shows the worst catalytic performance while the Ni/CeO2 (600, NO) is the most active catalyst in CO2 methanation. Their similar oxygen storage capacity reveals that the oxygen vacancies on Ni/CeO2 do not play a decisive role in the CO2 methanation ability. Therefore, the most likely contributing factor of Ni/CeO2 on methanation activity is Ni availability or else a synergistic effect of Ni availability and oxygen vacancy formation. The effect of different atmospheres and support calcination temperatures on the formation of oxygen vacancies is then rationalised. The higher calcination temperature of CeO2 significantly enhances the CeO2 crystallinity thereby lowering the concentration of oxygen vacancies, as confirmed in Tables 1 & 3 and Fig. S7. The lean oxygen atmosphere (He and 1 % NO/He) is likely to promote the formation of surface oxygen vacancies during the nitrate decomposition, with the similar OSCC observed in Table 3. The use of a low concentration of NO in He can further prevent Ni sintering and redistribution during nitrate decomposition, which can be seen in the different size of bulk NiO species in Fig. 3 and different Ni availability shown in Table 1. 3.6 Determination of interfacial active sites The work above focuses on the discussion of most likely contributing factors (Ni crystallite size, Ni availability, oxygen vacancies) of Ni/CeO2 on its methanation activity, and successfully demonstrated the positive role of Ni availability on activity enhancement. However, no clear correlation between the concentration of the oxygen vacancies from OSCC in Ni/CeO2 and CO2 conversion is observed in our work. It has been widely accepted that Ni supported on reducible oxides (e.g., TiO2, CeO2) possesses interfacial sites and therefore different types of CO2 activation sites when compared with those that utilise non-reducible oxides as the support (e.g., Al2O3, SiO2) [26,32]. H2 spillover on the reducible supports is thought to occur readily at interfacial sites [74]. Therefore, the concentration of surface Ni active sites and oxygen vacancies are thought to be important parameters affecting the formation of the Ni–CeO2-x interface. The concentration of the two types of sites (i.e. surface Ni active sites and oxygen vacancies) are then respectively estimated based on Ni availability (calculated by CO chemisorption and H2-TPD) and the oxygen defects from OSCC, as presented in Fig. 6 (a) respectively. The surface Ni active sites responsible for H2 dissociation, as estimated through CO chemisorption, are around 0.05, 0.02, 0.04 and 0.06 mmol/g in Ni/CeO2 (600, air), Ni/CeO2 (700, air), Ni/CeO2 (600, He) and Ni/CeO2 (600, NO), respectively. The surface Ni sites determined from H2-TPD are significantly higher, by 2 to 3 orders of magnitude, than the values obtained from CO chemisorption, with the corresponding values achieving around 0.09, 0.06, 0.08 and 0.11 mmol/g in Ni/CeO2 (600, air), Ni/CeO2 (700, air), Ni/CeO2 (600, He) and Ni/CeO2 (600, NO), respectively. As discussed above, the real concentration of surface Ni active sites should be lower than the results estimated by H2-TPD, and higher than those estimated by CO chemisorption. The surface exposed Ni active sites (NNi-sites, H2 and NNi-sites, CO) respectively determined from H2-TPD and CO chemisorption are applied to quantitively compare with oxygen vacancy (Ov) sites (Fig. 6(a)). The concentrations of Ov sites obtained from OSCC measurement in Ni/CeO2 (600, air), Ni/CeO2 (700, air), Ni/CeO2 (600, He), and Ni/CeO2 (600, NO) are approximately 0.32, 0.17, 0.37, and 0.40 mmol/g, respectively, which are significantly higher than that of surface Ni active sites. Given the positive impact of Ni availability on CO2 methanation detailed above, the concentration of interfacial Ni–Ov sites might be mainly determined by the exposed Ni active sites (Ni availability), especially if the concentration of Ov far exceeds that of Ni active sites. This might indicate that only oxygen vacancies in close contact with Ni are active for CH4 production. The relationship between the total accessible Ni–Ov interfacial sites / Ni active sites and the variation in CO2 conversion at 260 °C is depicted in Fig. 6(b). At this temperature (260 °C), all the samples exhibit less than 10 % CO2 conversion in Fig. 1(a), allowing us to extract the intrinsic activity of the catalysts. It can be observed that the CO2 conversion over different Ni/CeO2 show a directly proportional dependence on their number of Ni–Ov interfacial sites / Ni active sites, highlighting the significance of reactions involving H2 on Ni active sites, including H2 dissociation and H2 spillover, in the CO2 methanation process. 3.7 Determination of the reaction pathway Two common reaction pathways to produce CH4 have been proposed according to the different intermediates present in the reaction [75]. The first is termed the formate route in which mono and/or bidentate formate have been detected as the active species during reaction [76]. The second is the CO route although there are thought to be two possible reaction pathways in which either direct C−O cleavage (CO2 → CO) occurs else formates first form and decompose (CO2 → formate → CO) before CO hydrogenation takes place [20,76,77]. In situ DRIFTS experiments were carried out over all Ni/CeO2 at 150, 250 and 350 °C under CO2/H2/He flowing gas, as seen in Fig. 7 . The associated and dissociated CO2 species (carbonate, formate and CO) that form on the different samples during the reaction are similar. Two types of carbonate species including bidentate carbonates (∼1580 and 1290 cm−1) and monodentate carbonates (∼1340 cm−1) can be observed [26,78]. The bands at around 1410 cm−1 can be assigned as the bicarbonates which are generated from monodentate carbonate and surface OH groups on Ce sites [78,79]. CO formation occurs with the linear and bridge CO species respectively seen in the range of 2100–1950 cm−1 and 1950–1750 cm−1 [80]. In addition, the bands at 2840, 1540 and 1395 cm−1 assigned to formate species are observed over different Ni/CeO2 catalysts [21,81]. CH4 formation during the reaction can be confirmed by the presence of bands at ∼ 3015 and 1305 cm−1 [81]. With the higher reaction temperatures, the intensities of both carbonate and formate species decrease significantly, while the bands (3015 and 1305 cm−1) due to CH4 formation become more intense. It can be therefore deduced that CH4 formation accelerates at the cost of the consumption of the surface formate and carbonate species, suggesting the formation of first carbonates, then formate hydrogenation occurs to yield CH4. Meanwhile, differences in the band intensity pertaining to the amount of chemisorbed CO on the different samples cannot be ignored. It should also be noted that all the samples see a change in the types and intensities of the CO bands, especially at low reaction temperatures. Using the Ni/CeO2 (600, NO) sample as an exemplar, the intensity of the CO bands during the reaction at 150 °C are significantly enhanced when compared to those collected after the CO2 adsorption at the same temperature (Fig. S10), suggesting the additional formation of CO during the reaction of CO2 and H2. This suggests that the reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS), leading to the formation of CO is a key step in the reaction. When the reaction temperature is raised to 350 °C (higher conversion), the intensity of the CO band decreases in intensity evidencing the rapid hydrogenation of adsorbed CO, suggesting the high reactivity of CO(ads) during the CO2 methanation reaction. However, as discussed earlier, the lack of CO hydrogenation activity over the Ni/CeO2 suggests that this route may only play a small part in CH4 formation. The possibility that formate decomposition to yield CO is a key step in the reaction can be ruled out, otherwise the CO species generated from RWGS and/or CO2 dissociation and formate decomposition should occur at the same reaction sites and the CO and CO2 conversions shown in Fig. 1(b) and S1 should accordingly be similar. From the results of the in situ DRIFTS experiments discussed above, it appears that two reaction paths can be proposed. One is the “CO route” which occurs via RWGS/CO2 dissociation accordingly: CO2 → CO→C→CH4. The alternative is the “formate route” that occurs via CO2 → (bi)carbonates → formate → CH4 (dominant). For all Ni/CeO2 samples, it appears that these two reactions take place simultaneously and the formation and hydrogenation of both CO−Ni0 and formate species appear to be particularly advantaged by the presence of Ni−(O) − Ce interfacial sites. However, the “CO route” only plays a minor role in CO2 methanation, whereas the “formate route” is suggested to be the main path for CH4 formation. Thus, formate can be considered as the key intermediate species in CO2 methanation, and that formate hydrogenation is the rate-determining step (Fig. S11 and S12). 4 Summary and conclusion We have shown in this detailed and systematic study that the physico-chemical properties (Ni crystallite size, Ni availability, and oxygen vacancies etc.) can vary as a function of preparation procedures Ni/CeO2. The types of active and inactive sites can be summarised by the scheme shown in Fig. 8 . We observe that the concentration of Ni − Ov interfacial sites in Ni/CeO2 is mainly determined by the Ni active sites, and only the oxygen vacancies in close contact with Ni are favourable for the methane production. When ta layer of CeOx due to the SMSI effect covers the entire Ni NP, H2 dissociation is greatly supressed, subsequently, CO2 methanation does not occur at these inactive sites. The non-interfacial oxygen vacancies which are far away from the metallic Ni are also considered as inactive. On these sites, the carbonate species that form are also unlikely to be active. This phenomenon is best demonstrated when considering the samples calcined under different atmospheres (NO, He) where different Ni availability and a similar concentration of oxygen vacancies (much higher than Ni active sites) were achieved. Hence, we rationalise then the best performing catalysts comprise Ni metal that is highly dispersed and exposed over CeO2 and sufficient interfacial oxygen vacancies to pair with surface Ni sites for the formation of a significant Ni−(O)–Ce interface. The subtle changes in the preparation method (support calcination temperature and atmosphere) that bring about the differences in the physico-chemical properties of the sample don’t however change the methanation mechanism. During the reaction, the “formate route” (CO2 association and formate hydrogenation) appears to be the main pathway for the formation of CH4. The best catalytic performance exhibited by the Ni/CeO2 (600, NO) sample is characterised by an excellent hydrogenation ability towards formate species, consistent with the presence of the most abundant interfacial Ni−(O)–Ce sites. Future research efforts could realise improved performance by exploring and optimising this parameter for the next generation of Ni based catalysts with improved catalytic performance for CO2 methanation. In order to achieve this goal, our research suggests that better-dispersed Ni NPs can be obtained combining the use of CeO2 with a high surface area and by changing the calcination atmosphere by using/tuning the concentration of mild oxidants which in addition to dilute NO used here could involve using N2O or CO2. coredata.dc:description: The structure of a catalyst has a strong impact on its performance. Here we investigate the physicochemical properties of Ni/CeO2 in an attempt to draw structure–activity relationships for CO2 methanation. A combination of characterisation methods (X-ray diffraction (XRD), 4D Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (4D-STEM), CO chemisorption and oxygen storage capacity study etc.) clearly demonstrates the effect of Ni crystallite size, Ni availability (i.e. catalytically accessible Ni) and oxygen vacancies at the Ni-CeO2 interface in Ni/CeO2 during CO2 methanation. Among them, the role of exposed Ni active sites is highlighted, and two possible optimisation schemes i.e. changing the support calcination temperature and the final calcination atmosphere are proposed to obtain a better dispersal of Ni NPs (nanoparticles) on CeO2. Both modification methods do not affect the reaction route, and the activity differences of Ni/CeO2 can be explained by the various hydrogenation rate of formate species, as confirmed by in situ diffuse-reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) measurements.

coredata.dc:title: A detailed characterization study of Ni/CeO2 catalysts identifies Ni availability as the primary factor affecting CO2 methanation performance
